title: How to Resolve the Greenland Issue
preview: There's an elegant solution that is perhaps behind Donald Trump's "Art of the Deal" inspired negotiation strategy. You've read the book, haven't you?
body:
_“President Trump approaches diplomacy and engages in a very transactional manner, with economics as the foundation and driving force behind international affairs.”_

[Lt. Gen. Keith Kellogg,](https://apnews.com/article/trump-zelenskyy-kellogg-ukraine-intelligence-sharing-c5da1604549a8f5744a65f4ae581b3e4) President Trump’s former special envoy to Ukraine and Russia

_“Money was never a big motivation for me, except as a way to keep score. The real excitement is playing the game.”_

Donald J. Trump, _[Trump: The Art of the Deal](https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/1224415)_

It’s obvious that President Donald Trump thrives on transactions. He authored a ghostwritten book (Tony Schwartz) about it, “_[The Art of the Deal](https://ia601405.us.archive.org/19/items/TrumpTheArtOfTheDeal/Trump_%20The%20Art%20of%20the%20Deal.pdf)_.” I’ve heard stories from former U.S. senators and one former presidential GOP challenger about the way Trump views “moral” issues like abortion through a _purely_ transactional lens. The _Seattle Times_ once called Trump’s transactional approach “soulless.”

The most recent example is his reportedly advising House Republicans to be flexible on abortion policy when it comes to health insurance reform.

> “Now, you have to be a little flexible on Hyde,” Trump said in reference to the Hyde Amendment, the provision that prevents federal funds from being used on abortion services.
>
> “You know that you got to be a little flexible. You got to work something. You got to use ingenuity. You got to work,” Trump said in a speech to House Republicans at a policy retreat at the Kennedy Center.
>
> President Donald Trump, as reported by _[The Hill](https://thehill.com/policy/healthcare/5674971-trump-house-gop-obamacare-abortion-flexibility/)_

[![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!zcSB!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F02536cd7-a90a-44c0-b8d3-3a504169f148_3800x3040.png)](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!zcSB!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F02536cd7-a90a-44c0-b8d3-3a504169f148_3800x3040.png)

{{caption:Nuuk, the capital of Greenland, as seen by drone.}}

Trump wasn’t just referring to emerging health insurance reform legislation that he and Republicans in Congress are beginning to coalesce around. It also includes the thorny political issue of expired Obamacare subsidies for up to 20 million middle- and upper-middle-class Americans, mostly self-employed or small-business owners who don’t have access to or provide health insurance.

“Being flexible” on the moral issue of abortion isn’t something either “pro-choice” or “pro-life” supporters are very good at. Virginia Democrats, in one of their first acts last week, passed four Constitutional amendments, one of which enshrines access to abortion up until, _if not through_, birth (a doctor will have to sign off on any abortion after 26 weeks (in the third trimester), but that’s just a minor inconvenience for Planned Parenthood.

More about those lovely Constitutional amendments in a future post. Most passed on party-line votes. And wait until you learn about some of the legislation that Virginia Democrats, who have a “trifecta” lock on power in Richmond, have introduced and stand a good chance of enactment, from tax increases to a bill PROHIBITING counting machine-readable ballots to be counted by hand.

Now, why would Virginia Democrats be so interested in protecting - _[outlawing](https://lis.virginia.gov/bill-details/20261/HB968)_ - machine-readable ballots from being _hand-counted_? [Perhaps this book has the answer](https://www.amazon.com/Stolen-Elections-Takedown-Democracies-Worldwide/dp/B0FP5J7CS7/ref=sr_1_1?crid=4J1S5P73W4CF\&dib=eyJ2IjoiMSJ9.8o0au7s99sy9o9RrsYk6Ih0qS_L12gcHgfaQGqDKu7asKZ_Whc-IAWRLB7KC1QzjvFLTxE68WPn9P8IQpturjRBheOoFgzM_RamONuCqkmckgGNy71hNGdDjuyoFVV_5Nryhx5INtW1o1BHlTqd2O6CJJZejZYCZLWNiUU7PfIkDUFXN1xqrOw5cKbz05UiX8z5vgMWK0-VKgWnme6fQPd-OYgEeWTptb5DBkv70UNM.3mmONWAd3YC2jzBgBHK6gFqt1EyCjsE-XeXs3Rrngy4\&dib_tag=se\&keywords=stolen+elections+the+takedown+of+democracies+worldwide\&qid=1768832637\&sprefix=stolen+%2Caps%2C154\&sr=8-1). Looks like _a threat to democracy_ to me. That, and they want to _[expand](https://legiscan.com/VA/bill/HB978/2026)_ [sales taxes](https://legiscan.com/VA/bill/HB978/2026) and the hated personal property “car tax” to include electric lawn and landscaping equipment. [I kid you not](https://legiscan.com/VA/bill/HB557/2026).

Former Governor Ralph Northam (D-VA), a pediatric neurosurgeon, famously outlined the “pro-choice” view about ensuring abortion “survivors” meet their fate. Not much flexibility here, other than how you might keep a newborn infant “comfortable” while “adults” decide whether to fulfill the objective of the botched abortion.

{{youtube:Vx5QKTY-3MY}}

Find me any Democrats in Congress who disagree with the former Governor, not by their words, but _by their deeds_. But Trump is urging pro-life Republicans to cave on the issue. “_Art of the Deal_,” you know. It also doesn’t help that constitutional amendments have passed in several “red” states that enshrined practically unlimited abortion access, [including Ohio](https://ballotpedia.org/Ohio_Issue_1,_Right_to_Make_Reproductive_Decisions_Including_Abortion_Initiative_\(2023\)). For the record, any limit on abortion after viability except to protect the “life and health” of women is a [loophole](https://www.texasallianceforlife.org/life-and-health-of-mother-exceptions-legal-and-moral-standards/) big enough to fly a Space Shuttle through.

So, in that sense, Trump is soulless.

Now, let’s discuss Greenland.

[![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!eTl8!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F4fe6a588-ecc3-4dc8-bd27-1e9bd20dc2a5_570x532.png)](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!eTl8!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F4fe6a588-ecc3-4dc8-bd27-1e9bd20dc2a5_570x532.png)

Trump’s opening gambit is classic for him but not unprecedented. He wants to “buy” Greenland, an 830,000-square-mile island with a 27,000-mile coastline, 56,000 residents (mostly native [Inuit](https://www.britannica.com/place/Greenland/People)), and one very important US military installation (Thule, now called [Pituffik Space Base](https://www.petersonschriever.spaceforce.mil/pituffik-sb-greenland/), which serves as an early-warning missile-detection center and probably more). It’s more than three times the size of Texas. Up to 85 percent of Greenland is a big sheet of ice, but it’s also a reservoir of “rare earth” mineral deposits. Norway, then Denmark-Norway (they were once combined and began colonizing and claiming Greenland in the 16th Century. Under the Treaty of Keil, when Norway and Denmark split, Greenland became a Danish territory, with a population of 6 million.

Denmark’s military is smaller than New York City’s police department. They also include the much smaller, but strategically located, Faroe Islands, a territory between Iceland and Europe with a population of 50,000.

Several presidents, starting with Andrew Jackson in 1832, have sought to purchase or claim Greenland. So did Andrew Johnson, during whose Administration Secretary of State William Seward purchased Alaska from Russia in 1867 (“[Seward’s folly](https://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/march-30/sewards-folly)”). Seward also wanted to annex both Greenland and Iceland when he bought Alaska. It’s helpful to remember that 40 percent of the current United States was acquired through purchase, including Thomas Jefferson’s constitutionally dubious Louisiana Purchase from France, USA’s purchase of the Virgin Islands from Denmark, and the Gadsden Purchase from Mexico.

As the Cold War with the Soviet Union commenced post World War II, President Harry Truman wanted to buy Greenland. He established Thule Air Base there in 1950. And his successor, Dwight Eisenhower, kept a close eye on the massive island. Tiny Denmark, with a population smaller than Indiana's, for its part, has been highly accommodating to the United States. At least until now.

[![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!iMpz!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F478dab61-969f-4b3d-bab3-ac3bed48bb65_474x320.jpeg)](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!iMpz!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F478dab61-969f-4b3d-bab3-ac3bed48bb65_474x320.jpeg)

{{caption:European leaders respond to Trump’s demands to purchase Greenland}}

Europe responded to Trump’s latest bombast with its classic and reflexive pearl clutching. They proclaimed horror at the idea of Trump trying to buy and then threatening military action (he didn’t, really; [he just never took the option off the table](https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2026/jan/19/donald-trump-greenland-denmark-nobel-nato-europe-live-latest-news-updates)). They promised to send symbolic troops (platoons, actually) to Greenland (they’re probably not there yet) to show a commitment to “protect” Greenland from Trump and other foreign threats. Also, reflexively, the Danes and others demanded meetings with Secretary of State Marco Rubio.

[![The seal of the United States of America is displayed on the exterior of the United States Consulate on March 26, 2025 in Nuuk, Greenland. A visit...](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!31l6!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F1a3015a1-1acd-49ca-9346-8da4df5935bf_500x333.jpeg)](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!31l6!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F1a3015a1-1acd-49ca-9346-8da4df5935bf_500x333.jpeg)

{{caption:US consulate in Nuuk, Greenland}}

Trump [floated a trial balloon](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/trump-administration-mulls-payments-sway-greenlanders-join-us-2026-01-08/) offering payments of $10,000 to $100,000 per resident or adult in Greenland. More European pearl clutching ensued. If Trump offered that to Cubans, it might finally result in a free Cuba (although Cuba has more than 10 million people, _way_ _larger than Denmark_).

Meanwhile, China, which does not border the Arctic (Russia is in the way, and China isn’t letting that stop them), published [a 2018 white paper](https://www.uaf.edu/caps/resources/policy-documents/china-arctic-policy-2018.pdf) outlining its Arctic strategy, including a “Polar” Belt and Road Initiative. It doesn’t specifically mention Greenland, but it emphasizes access to fishing. Some believe that [China’s massive overfishing](https://nationalinterest.org/blog/energy-world/chinas-overfishing-problem-is-everyones-problem) in global waters extends to Greenland’s waters as well. Fishing is Greenland’s largest private industry.

[![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!cNKq!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F42be004e-1c12-4892-8227-b8eb49b0ca34_737x540.png)](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!cNKq!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F42be004e-1c12-4892-8227-b8eb49b0ca34_737x540.png)

Greenland came very close during the first Trump Administration to [signing a contract with Communist Chinese enterprises](https://securingdemocracy.gmfus.org/incident/chinese-state-owned-company-bids-in-airport-construction-contract-that-would-grant-it-significant-influence-in-greenland/) to expand two airports. Alarmed, the Trump Administration pressured Denmark to step in. They did, and now Denmark has funded the airport expansions. As anyone who pays attention to China knows, when they build airports, ports, and other infrastructure, it comes with very favorable financial terms that are often unattainable, resulting in Chinese takeovers (see: [Sri Lanka)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hambantota) and a military presence. Chinese companies already have an interest in several mining operations in Greenland and [own and operate icebreakers](https://georgetownsecuritystudiesreview.org/2019/02/14/how-to-keep-china-out-of-greenland-start-by-asking-the-greenlandic-people/) in the region.

Trump appears to have gotten the idea to buy Greenland from fellow billionaire [Ronald Lauder](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/jan/15/ronald-lauder-billionaire-donor-donald-trump-ukraine-greenland) in 2018.

[![Ronald Lauder stands with his arms crossed](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!1r0K!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F7f87c4b5-4892-42ed-af13-a6a43d694233_480x384.jpeg)](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!1r0K!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F7f87c4b5-4892-42ed-af13-a6a43d694233_480x384.jpeg)

{{caption:Billionaire Ronald Lauder, who is credited with suggesting that Trump buy Greenland. Lauder has interests on the island.}}

In recent years, Denmark has granted increased autonomy to Greenland, including instituting “home rule.” That resulted in Greenland almost contracting with Chinese construction companies to build the two airports mentioned previously 7 years ago. _Oops_.

So, is there a deal to be had between the US and Denmark (and Greenland)? In short, yes, but it will come in steps, with lots of ifs and buts, and almost certainly require a treaty and possibly other agreements that will require Senate ratification and a two-thirds vote (_that will be interesting,_ since Democrats are inclined to oppose _anything_ Trump negotiates, _because_). Trump may try to negotiate a “memorandum” rather than a treaty to avoid a Senate vote, as others have before him (see: the [1993 Budapest Memorandum](https://www.wilsoncenter.org/sites/default/files/media/documents/publication/Issue%20Brief%20No%203--The%20Breach--Final4.pdf)), but that’s hard to imagine given what “protectorate” status would require (a major US military commitment).

First, it recognizes that neither NATO nor Denmark is in any position to protect Greenland, despite protestations to the contrary. It also recognizes that the threat to Greenland from [China](https://www.thearcticinstitute.org/tortuous-path-china-win-win-strategy-greenland/), and possibly Russia, which [sends its nuclear submarines on errands up and down the coast](https://www.twz.com/sea/greenland-absolutely-critical-for-hunting-russian-submarines-top-u-s-general-in-europe), is real.

Second, Denmark allows Greenland to become independent, a course it was already on. Denmark has already said that it would respect the results of a referendum granting independence to the Big Ice Rock.

[![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!fwhL!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Fff3e3fcd-abb0-4ff4-b12c-29067d7836d4_1279x1600.jpeg)](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!fwhL!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Fff3e3fcd-abb0-4ff4-b12c-29067d7836d4_1279x1600.jpeg)

Third, perhaps as part of a referendum, the United States negotiates a treaty with Greenland to make it a “protectorate.” Greenland would retain its independence, but the United States would basically provide the Island’s national defense and have a role in its foreign policy. Perhaps Greenland could become a part of NATO as a result. The US would enforce Greenland's territorial waters and help protect its significant fishing industry, especially against Chinese vessels.

Does the United States have any protectorates now? No, but at various times, it has. Don’t confuse 14 US “territories,” where residents are US citizens and pay taxes (see: Guam, the US Virgin Islands, the Northern Marianas, Puerto Rico, etc.), versus protectorates, which my [Freespoke](https://freespoke.com/) search engine AI defines it this way:

> “The concept of a protectorate involves an autonomous territory protected diplomatically or militarily by a stronger state, while retaining formal sovereignty and managing its internal affairs.”

In the past, countries like the Philippines and Puerto Rico started off as protectorates. Cuba, Haiti, and the Dominican Republic, too. But all besides Puerto Rico were granted independence, as the PR became a territory with a non-voting delegate in the US House of Representatives, as has Guam, the Virgin Islands, the District of Columbia, the Northern Mariana Islands, and American Samoa.

Some may suggest that Canada should “take over” Greenland, given its proximity as a neighbor and Arctic nation. But that’s laughable. Canada’s Navy has a whopping 40 vessels to patrol the world’s longest shoreline (about 150,000 miles), including 12 Halifax-class frigates and _four_ diesel-powered submarines. But as of late 2025, it was reported that 54 percent of the navy’s frigates, submarines, arctic and offshore patrol ships, and maritime coastal defense vessels were considered “unserviceable,” and personnel problems remained “dire.”

Canada’s Royal Air Force consists mostly of 70-80 CF-18s, many of them purchased used from Australia, and upgrading to “Gen 5” F-35s remains controversial because, well, _Trump_ (they’ve “promised” to purchase 80, but have only funded and received 16 thus far). In retaliation, Prime Minister Mark Carney, who just signed a huge “strategic cooperation” deal with Communist China, is leaning towards buying Sweden’s Gen 4 Gripen fighter, which no other NATO nation uses except Hungary and the Czech Republic (and, since 2024, when they finally joined NATO, Sweden). With all due respect to Sweden, Canada should stick with the F-35. It’s a no-brainer. By comparison, the US has upwards of 3,400 fighter/interceptor aircraft - Navy, Marine Corps, and Air Force - including F-15, F-16, F-18, F-22, and F-35 aircraft.

[![First Gripen E for Sweden Flies | Aviation International News](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!N0k-!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F416b53d5-9e46-43d5-8abb-1df6a1fc53a1_1200x630.jpeg)](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!N0k-!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F416b53d5-9e46-43d5-8abb-1df6a1fc53a1_1200x630.jpeg)

{{caption:Sweden’s “Gen 4” Gripen E fighter}}

Canada’s Navy consists of, _at best_, 8,400 sailors. The USS Gerald Ford _alone_, America’s largest aircraft carrier, has upwards of 4,500 sailors. And we have 11 active nuclear-powered aircraft carriers. Canada? _Zero_.

At least Canada is finally stepping up to its commitment to invest at least 2% of its Gross Domestic Product in national defense. For years, Canada has ranked _last_ among NATO members in military spending, relying instead on the USA and NORAD (the North American Aerospace Defense Command, which they share with the US).

[![Canadian Victoria Class Submarine](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!syp1!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Fb89db1d8-c59a-4635-a7af-bd0d449c8651_500x294.jpeg)](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!syp1!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Fb89db1d8-c59a-4635-a7af-bd0d449c8651_500x294.jpeg)

{{caption:The US Coast Guard escorts one of Canada’s four Victoria-class diesel submarines. The US has about 70 submarines, nuclear and diesel powered.}}

Would Trump settle for granting Greenland protectorate status? I think so, and it would be a win-win. The US would win full responsibility for Greenland’s defense. Greenland would be free and independent, with protection from the United States and, by extension, NATO (North Atlantic Treaty Organization). US investment in Greenland would grow, especially in rare earth minerals. And China and Russia would be kept at bay. No “Polar Belt and Road Initiative” here. It would also free Denmark from the responsibility it really isn’t equipped to handle, at least with respect to Chinese and Russian incursions. It took Trump to prevent them from allowing Chinese control of at least two Greenland airports, while Denmark was asleep at the switch.

Denmark’s military is minuscule. It has 20 commissioned ships, 43 F-35s, and up to 21,000 active duty military personnel. The US? We have nearly _1.4 million active duty personnel_. Denmark’s military is smaller but arguably better equipped (at least in the air) than Canada’s, despite being six times smaller in population.

Denmark only has 150 military personnel permanently assigned to Greenland. Each one probably has a white flag to wave in case someone invades.

[![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!qd9a!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Fdd6b207e-f28d-418f-bb1d-be92d37fcf23_1024x1024.jpeg)](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!qd9a!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Fdd6b207e-f28d-418f-bb1d-be92d37fcf23_1024x1024.jpeg)

{{caption:A Denmark soldier waves the white flag on Greenland. Image by Google Gemini AI.}}

Understanding Trump isn’t that hard, really, and it starts with [reading his book](https://ia601405.us.archive.org/19/items/TrumpTheArtOfTheDeal/Trump_%20The%20Art%20of%20the%20Deal.pdf).

> "The final key to the way I promote is bravado. I play to people's fantasies. People may not always think big themselves, but they can still get very excited by those who do. That's why a little hyperbole never hurts. People want to believe that something is the biggest and the greatest and the most spectacular. I call it truthful hyperbole. It's an innocent form of exaggeration, and a very effective form of promotion."
>
> Donald Trump, _Trump: Art of the Deal_

Trump also said in his book that “Sometimes, part of making a deal is denigrating your competition." _Have any European leaders read the book?_ I doubt it.

“Buying Greenland” might be bravado, but “protectorate” status meets most of America’s strategic imperatives. Let’s hope this is what he has in mind. It would be a win-win, unlike making Canada the 51st State, which remains _a really bad idea,_ and fortunately, a non-starter.

> “MY STYLE of deal-making is quite simple and straightforward. I aim very high, and then I just keep pushing and pushing and pushing to get what I’m after.”
> ― Donald Trump, _[Trump: The Art of the Deal](https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/1224415)_
